description: The Ali and Nino statue is an 8-meter-tall kinetic sculpture created by Georgian artist Tamara Kvesitadze in 2010, standing as one of Batumi's most iconic landmarks along the Black Sea Boulevard. Originally titled 'Man and Woman' when it debuted at the Venice Biennale in 2007, this moving steel sculpture weighs 7 tons and consists of two somewhat transparent figures made of stacked steel segments. Every evening at 7:00 PM, the figures begin their mesmerizing 10-minute cycle, slowly moving toward each other, merging as their segments pass through one another, only to separate again without ever truly connecting. The sculpture has become synonymous with the tragic love story from Kurban Said's 1937 novel 'Ali and Nino,' about the romance between a Muslim Azerbaijani boy and a Christian Georgian girl in Baku during 1918-1920, earning it the nickname 'The Caucasian Romeo and Juliet.' Located at the entrance of Batumi Harbor within the Park of Wonders, this computer-controlled masterpiece took 10 months to construct and has been included in the Top 10 Most Romantic Monuments list published in 2016. The sculpture symbolizes eternal motion, love transcending boundaries, and the convergence of cultures, though the artist herself revealed it was born from personal heartbreak, designed to express 'being together for a moment with someone, and then you lose it.' At night, the monument transforms with bright, changing colors—red and blue lights that give the figures even more life, creating a magical atmosphere against the backdrop of the Black Sea.
highlights: The 8-meter-tall sculpture weighs 7 tons and consists entirely of stacked steel discs that create semi-transparent figures capable of passing through each other during their movement cycle.

Every evening at 7:00 PM, the computer-controlled figures begin their 10-minute movement sequence, slowly approaching, merging as their segments interweave, and then separating—a cycle that repeats continuously throughout the evening.

The sculpture was originally titled 'Man and Woman' when it debuted at the Venice Biennale in 2007, and the association with Ali and Nino came from the public rather than the artist, who never referenced the famous novel.
The kinetic sculpture took 10 months to construct and was installed on Batumi Boulevard in 2010, becoming one of the city's most photographed landmarks within the Park of Wonders.

Artist Tamara Kvesitadze designed the sculpture during a moment of personal heartbreak, intending to capture the fleeting nature of connection—'being together for a moment with someone, and then you lose it.'

At night, the sculpture is illuminated with bright, changing colors, particularly red and blue lights, creating an ethereal glow that transforms the monument into a magical display visible from various points along the seven-kilometer Boulevard.

The figures never truly unite during their movement—their segments pass between each other but never connect, symbolizing the tragic reality of lovers who can never be together, mirroring the novel's ending where Ali is killed by war.
Located approximately 50 meters from the Alphabet Tower and the Ferris wheel at the entrance to Batumi Harbor, the statue has become part of an iconic cluster of Batumi's modern landmarks.
The sculpture has been included in the Top 10 Most Romantic Monuments list published in 2016 and is often called 'The Statue of Love' or 'The Caucasian Romeo and Juliet.'

The movement is described by visitors as 'mesmerizing'—impossible not to watch for the full 10 minutes, and then watch it again and again, standing transfixed by the emotional choreography of steel and light.
tips: Arrive before 7:00 PM to secure a good viewing spot, as crowds gather quickly once the movement begins at precisely 7:00 PM each evening, and the performance area can become quite congested during peak season.

Visit during sunset hours (around 6:30-7:30 PM) to capture the sculpture against a breathtaking sky, then stay for the illuminated display after dark when the changing colored lights create the most dramatic photographic opportunities.

The sculpture is only accessible from mid-to-late spring through September, as it appears to be closed or non-operational during winter months—one visitor reported the figures did not move on January 1st.
Bring a wide-angle lens or step back to include the nearby Ferris wheel in your composition, as this creates the iconic Batumi photograph that captures multiple landmarks in a single frame.

Plan to watch at least two complete 10-minute cycles to fully appreciate the movement—the first viewing is often spent in amazement, while the second allows you to notice the intricate details of how the segments interweave.
Visit Café Batumi, located directly near the Ali and Nino statue and beach, for Western-style coffee, fresh pastries, and a cozy atmosphere where you can relax before or after viewing the sculpture.
The attraction is completely free to visit and accessible 24/7 along Batumi Boulevard, making it an easy addition to any evening stroll along the seven-kilometer seaside promenade.
Combine your visit with nearby attractions within walking distance: the Alphabet Tower (50 meters away), the Ferris wheel, Dancing Fountains, and the broader Park of Wonders entertainment area.
For the best photography, position yourself to capture the Black Sea backdrop during the merging sequence, especially when the sunset colors reflect off the water and the steel segments.

Avoid visiting only during the day if possible—while daytime offers clear views, the nighttime ambiance with special lighting adds a layer of magic to the experience that defines why this sculpture has become so beloved.
If visiting during peak summer season (June-September), expect larger crowds but also the warmest weather and longest daylight hours to explore the entire Boulevard area before the evening show.

Take time to explore the seven-kilometer Batumi Boulevard after watching the sculpture—the surrounding area features lush greenery, elegant fountains, a bike path, and over 40,000 tree-plants, making it the city's main attraction.
vibe: The atmosphere around Ali and Nino embodies romantic melancholy mixed with collective wonder. As 7:00 PM approaches, an anticipatory energy builds along the Boulevard as locals and tourists alike gather around the steel figures, positioning themselves for the best view. Once the movement begins, a hush often falls over the crowd—punctuated only by camera clicks and whispered commentary—as people stand transfixed by the slow, deliberate choreography of metal and meaning. The experience is both intimate and communal, as strangers share space witnessing what feels like a private moment between two lovers, made monumental. The transparency of the figures creates an ethereal quality, especially against the backdrop of the Black Sea, where the setting sun or the deep blue of evening sky is visible through their forms. When night falls and the colored lights activate—shifting between reds and blues—the mood transforms from contemplative to magical, almost theatrical. There's something hypnotic about the 10-minute cycle that makes it impossible to walk away after just one viewing; visitors consistently report watching it 'again and again,' pulled into the emotional gravity of figures that merge but never truly connect. The surrounding Park of Wonders adds a carnivalesque element with its nearby Ferris wheel and entertainment attractions, yet the statue itself commands a more reverent attention. Unlike the bustling energy of the rest of Batumi Boulevard, this particular spot cultivates a sense of poignant beauty—a place where engineering and emotion converge, where the mechanical becomes meaningful, and where the story of impossible love is retold without words every ten minutes, night after night.
expectations: The statue will be massive and imposing, dominating the Batumi Boulevard skyline based on photos and videos seen online.
The figures will physically embrace and touch during the merging sequence, creating a romantic 'kiss' or connection between the two lovers.
The sculpture is specifically designed to illustrate the Ali and Nino novel and was created as a deliberate tribute to this famous love story.
The movement happens only once per evening at exactly 7:00 PM, making it a one-time performance you must time perfectly to witness.
Winter is a fine time to visit Batumi and see the sculpture operate throughout the year, similar to any other outdoor monument.
reality: At 8 meters tall, the statue is actually smaller than many visitors expect, especially when compared to the nearby Ferris wheel and Alphabet Tower—some describe it as 'very small' compared to photographs that make it appear monumental.

The figures never truly touch or embrace—their stacked segments pass through each other without connecting, a deliberate artistic choice symbolizing that the lovers can never actually unite, making the sculpture more heartbreaking than romantic.

The artist Tamara Kvesitadze never referenced the Ali and Nino novel at all; she designed it during personal heartbreak and titled it 'Man and Woman' for the Venice Biennale, with the Ali and Nino association coming entirely from the public after installation.

The 10-minute movement cycle repeats continuously throughout the evening after the initial 7:00 PM start time, so you have multiple opportunities to watch and don't need to time your arrival with military precision.

The sculpture is only accessible from mid-to-late spring through September and appears to be non-operational during winter months, with reports of the figures not moving on cold weather dates like January 1st.
unique_facts: The sculpture's original name was 'Man and Woman' when it debuted at the Venice Biennale in 2007, and nobody—including the artist—is entirely sure how the Ali and Nino association became so firmly attached to the work.

Tamara Kvesitadze designed the sculpture at a moment of personal heartbreak, saying: 'I wanted to make what was my idea of being together for a moment, with someone, and then you lose it,' making it autobiographical rather than literary.

The entire 7-ton sculpture is computer-controlled, with both figures operating on a synchronized system that requires precise engineering to ensure the stacked steel discs pass through each other without collision.
Construction took 10 months from design to installation, with the sculpture first designed in 2007 but not installed on Batumi Boulevard until 2010, representing a three-year development period.
The sculpture was included in the Top 10 Most Romantic Monuments list published in 2016, despite its creator's intention being about loss rather than romance.

Kurban Said's 1937 novel 'Ali and Nino' tells the story of an Azerbaijani Muslim boy and Georgian Christian girl in Baku during 1918-1920, with Ali being killed by war after they finally unite—the sculpture's non-connecting figures perfectly mirror this tragic ending.

The sculpture is sometimes called 'The Caucasian Romeo and Juliet,' drawing parallels to Shakespeare's tragedy where lovers from opposing sides cannot escape the conflicts that ultimately destroy them.

The 8-meter figures are made of stacked steel discs that create a semi-transparent effect, allowing viewers to see through the segments to the Black Sea and sky beyond, creating an ethereal, ghostly quality.

At night, the sculpture is illuminated with changing colors—particularly red and blue lights—that undulate across the moving figures, creating what some describe as an 'emotional mood' through the interplay of color and movement.
The sculpture stands at the entrance of Batumi Harbor within the Park of Wonders, approximately 50 meters from both the Alphabet Tower and the Ferris wheel, creating a cluster of modern landmarks.

Visitors consistently describe the experience as 'mesmerizing' and report being unable to walk away after one viewing, often watching multiple 10-minute cycles while standing 'transfixed' by the slow choreography.

The figures are deliberately designed without arms, a stylistic choice that some visitors find puzzling but which contributes to their abstract, universal quality rather than depicting specific individuals.
surprises: The sculpture's scale is deceptive in photographs—many visitors are surprised by how much smaller it appears in person, especially when standing next to the towering Ferris wheel and Alphabet Tower.

The movement is extraordinarily slow and meditative, taking the full 10 minutes to complete one cycle, which creates a contemplative rather than dramatic experience that feels more like watching a sunset than a performance.
Despite being one of Batumi's most famous attractions, the sculpture is completely free to visit with no tickets, barriers, or restricted access—you simply walk up to it along the public Boulevard.

The area around the statue is part of a vibrant carnival-like atmosphere with the Park of Wonders, Ferris wheel, and entertainment options, creating an unexpected contrast between the sculpture's emotional depth and its festive surroundings.

You can watch the cycle repeat indefinitely after 7:00 PM—it's not a one-time performance but a continuous loop, giving you flexibility to arrive anytime in the evening and still experience multiple viewings.

The sculpture is more moving emotionally than visitors anticipate—many report feeling genuinely affected by watching the figures merge without connecting, describing it as 'heartbreaking' rather than simply 'romantic.'

Café Batumi is located directly adjacent to the statue, offering an unexpected convenience where you can sip coffee or enjoy pastries while watching the sculpture through the café windows or from outdoor seating.

The sculpture faces the Black Sea with the water as backdrop, and during sunset, the transparent steel segments frame the changing colors of sky and water, creating an unexpected natural gallery effect.

Local guides recommend visiting in summer not just for the sculpture but because that's when Batumi Boulevard's full seven-kilometer stretch is most vibrant, with the statue being just one highlight among dozens of attractions.

The changing colored lights at night are far more dramatic than daytime viewing suggests—the red and blue illumination transforms the sculpture into something almost otherworldly, making the nighttime experience essential.

Despite the tragic story, the atmosphere around the sculpture during viewing is surprisingly communal and warm, with strangers sharing space, commenting to each other, and collectively experiencing the movement together.

The sculpture operates on such precise engineering that the segments pass through each other without any visible collision or hesitation, creating an almost magical illusion that seems to defy the physical reality of 7 tons of steel in motion.
